field_edited_text.value:
Because of the high percentage of car
ownership, there is less emphasis on walk-in
trade and the need for off-street parking and
improved traffic circulation is greater. The high
proportion of owner-occupied stores, together
with a high number of tenant-businessmen, will
require a planning program that provides
investment opportunities. Because of these
factors, rehabilitation will take more time to
accomplish, but should be economically
feasible because of the condition of buildings.

The likelihood of only a moderate population
Increase and a trend toward an increase in lower
income families living in the area will make it
necessary to strengthen the shopping area and
attract customers from other parts of the city.
This will necessitate the improvement of the
public market.

b. Existing Physical Relationships
The trade area consists mainly of single-family

row houses, with a few pockets of two-family
and multi-family housing on the fringes. This
points to the possibility of increasing
population densities to create more market
potential for stores in the area. Another
possibility is to take advantage of the
expanding Johns Hopkins Hospital complex by
providing for the development of multi-family
housing in the immediate area and by providing
goods and services required by hospital
personnel.

Monument Street is part of a one-way street
system and ways of reducing or eliminating
congestion should be provided.

c. Present City Programs and Proposals
These include a conservation program
immediately surrounding the study area and
possible rehabilitation and clearance nearby.
These proposals provide an opportunity to

increase population densities and strengthi'ép the

trade area potential. ;
A proposed subway loop in the area is
considerably removed from the shopping
center. If strategically relocated, it could serve
both the Johns Hopkins complex and the
shopping center.

d. Environmental Problems

Apart from scattered pockets of structural and
functional decay and traffic congestion in the
area of the market, environmental problems are
considerably less acute than in the other study
areas, making it easier to accomplish an
improvement program.
